prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for buying pregnant wife yoga pass for her birthday
My wife is 16 weeks pregnant.  She has a something called hypermesis which is "morning sickness" all the time, even waking up in the middle of the night to vomit.   I told her to ask her doctor for a medical leave so she is currently on temporary disability.  She stays in bed most of the day and only leaves the house to go to the hospital where she gets IV fluids for dehydration/vitamin deficiency.     
I know I always feel better when I exercise and it helps with depression.  I think she is getting depressed because she misses her job.  I think she should leave the house and get some fresh air and stretch, so I got her a yoga pass for her birthday.   I researched local studios and found one that had prenatal yoga.   When she got the email gift certificate while I was at work, she didn't call to say thank you.  When I got home, I asked her if she got the email and she just gave me a look.  I could tell she didn't like my present.  She says she is too sick to do yoga.   Ok, maybe.   She thinks it is a rude present and that I am "tone deaf."  I can get her another present...don't know what.   I don't think my present makes me a bad person, though.   She might feel better soon and want to take yoga classes.  She told her friends about it and they agreed with her that I am being an asshole.  I think it is rude to be so critical of my present.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author bought a prenatal yoga pass for his pregnant wife for her birthday. The wife has hypermesis, which is really severe morning sickness, leading her to be on temporary disability. She's staying in bed, going to the hospital for IV fluids. He noticed she might be depressed from missing work and thought yoga could help. But she didn't like the gift, found it rude, and her friends agreed she's the asshole.

Hmm. The author's intention was good—he wanted to help her feel better by getting her active and maybe reduce depression. But the wife is in a very fragile state physically and emotionally. Hypermesis is serious; she's vomiting so much that she needs IV fluids. She's on bed rest. So suggesting yoga might be seen as insensitive because she's already struggling with daily activities. Even prenatal yoga might be too much for her right now. 

He didn't consult her about her needs before buying the gift. Maybe she's too unwell to think about exercise, and the gift could be seen as not considering her current health condition. The wife's reaction is understandable if she feels that he's not respecting her medical situation. Her friends supporting her view also indicates that the gesture was inappropriate in this context.

But the author's intention was to help, so maybe he's not entirely wrong. However, the action itself might have been inappropriate given her condition. So maybe the answer is A (he's in the wrong) because he didn't consider her current health state and the gift was not suitable for her situation, even if his intentions were good.
